body: A wife’s brother or a sister’s husband. There is not any re-lationskip, but only affinity, between broth-ers-ln-law. Farmers’ L. & T. Co. v. Iowa water Co. (C. C.) 80 Fed. 469. See State v. Foster, 112 La. 533, 36 South. 554

title: Bruarium
body: In old English law. A heath ground; ground where heath grows. Spelman

title: Brugbote
body: See Brigbote

title: Bruillus
body: In old English law. A wood or grove; a thicket or clump of trees in a park or forest Cowell

title: Bruise
body: In medical jurisprudence. A contusion; an injury upou the flesh of a per-son with a bluut or heavy instrument, with-out solution of coutinulty, or without break-ing the skin. Shadock v. Road Co., 79 Mich. 7, 44 N. W. 158; State v. owen, 5 N. C. 452, 4 Am. Dec. 571

title: Brukbarn
body: In old Swedish law. The child of a woman conceiving after a rape, which was made legitimate. Literally, the chlld of a struggle. Burrill

title: Brutum Fulmen
body: An empty noise; an empty threat

title: Bubble
body: An extravagant or unsubstan-tial project for extensive operations lu busl-ness or commerce, generally founded on a fictitious or exaggerated prospectus, to ensnare unwary investors. Companies formed on such a basis or for such purposes are called “bubble companies.” The term is chiefly used in England

title: Bubble Act
body: The statute 6 Geo. I. c. 18, “for restraining several extravagant and unwarrantable practices herein mentioned," was so called. It prescribed penalties for the formation of companies with little or no cap-ital, with the intention, by means of allur-ing advertisements, of obtaining money from the public by the sale of shares. Such un-dertakings were then commonly called “buh-bles." This legislation was prompted by the collapse of the “South Sea Project,” which, as Blackstone says, “had beggared half the nation.” It was mostly repealed by the stat-ute 6 Geo. IV. c. 91

title: Bucket Shop
body: An office or place (oth-er than a regularly incorporated or licensed

title: Buckstall
body: A toil, net, or snare, to take deer. 4 Inst 306

title: Budget
body: A name given in England to the statement annually presented to parliament by the chancellor of the exchequer, con-talning the estimates of the national revenue and expenditure

title: Buggery
body: A carnal copulation against nature; and this is either by the confusion of species,—that is to say, a man or a woman with a brute beast,—or of sexes, as a man with a man, or man unnaturally with a wo-man. 3 Inst 58; 12 Coke, 36. Ausman v. Veal, 10 Ind. 356, 71 Am. Dec. 331; Com. v. J., 21 Pa. Co. Ct. R. 626

title: Building
body: A structure or edifice erected by the hand of man, composed of natural materials, as stone or wood, and Intended for use or convenience. Truesdell v. Gray, 13 Gray (Mass.) 311; State v. Moore, 61 Mo. 276; Clark v. State, 69 wis. 203, 33 N. W. 436, 2 Am. St. Rep. 732

title: Building And Loan Association
body: An organization created for the pur-pose of accumulating a fund by the monthly subscriptions and savings of its members to assist them in bailding or purchasing for themselves dwellings or real estate by the loan to them of the requisite money from the funds of the association. McCauley v. Association, 97 Tenn. 421, 37 S. W. 212, 35 L. R. A. 244, 56 Am. St. Rep. S13; Cook v. Association, 104 Ga. 814, 30 S. E. 911; Pfels-ter v. Association, 19 W. Va. 093

title: Building Lease
body: A lease of land for a long term of years, usually 99, at a rent called a “ground rent,” the lessee covenant-ing to erect certaln edifices thereon according to specification, and to maintain the same, etc., during the term

title: Building Lien
body: The statutory lien of a material-man or contractor for the erection of a building. Lumber Co. v. Holt, 60 Neb. 80, 82 N. W. 112, 83 Am. St. Rep. 512; June v. Doke, 35 Tex. Clv. App. 240, 80 S. W. 406

title: Building Society
body: An association in which the subscriptions of the members

title: Bulk
body: Unbroken packages. Merchandise which is neither counted, weighed, nor measured

title: Bull
body: In eccleslastlcal law. An lnstru-ment granted by the pope of Rome, and sealed with a seal of lead, containing some decree, commandment, or other public act, emanating from the pontiff. Bull, in this sense, corresponds with edict or letters pat-ent from other governments. Cowell; 4 Bl. Comm. 110; 4 Steph. Comm. 177, 179

title: Bulla
body: A seal used by the Romnn emperors, during the lower empire; and which was of four kinds,—gold, silver, wax, and lead

title: Bulletin
body: An officially published notice or announcement concerning the progress of matters of public importance. In France, the registry of the laws

title: Bullion
body: Gold and silver Intended to be coined. The term la usually applied to a quantity of these metals ready for tlie mint, but as yet lying in bars, plates, lumps, or other masses; but it may also include orna-ments or dishes of gold and silver, or foreign coins not current as money, when intended to be descriptive of its adaptability to be coined, and not of other purposes to which it may be put. Hope Min. Co. v. Kennon, 3 Mont. 44; Thalheim v. State, 38 Fin. 169, 20 South. 938; Counsel v. Min. Co., 5 Daly (N. Y.) 77

title: Bum-Bailiff
body: A person employed to dun one for a debt; a bailiff employed to ar-rest a debtor. Probably a vulgar corruption of “bound-bailiff,” (q. r.)

title: Bunda
body: In old English iaw. A bound, boundary, border, or limit, (terminus, limes

title: Buoy
body: In maritime law. A piece of wood or cork, or a barrel, raft, or other thlng, made secure and floating upon a stream or bay, intended as a guide and warning to mariners, by marking a spot where the water is shallow, or where there is a reef or other danger to navigation, or to murk the course of a devious channel

title: Burden Of Proof
body: (Lat. onus probandi.) In the law of evldence. The neces-slty or duty of affirmatively provlng a fact or facts in dispute on an issue raised between the parties In a cause, willett v. Rich, 142 Mass. 356, 7 N. E. 776, 56 Am. Rep. 684; wilder v. Cowles, 100 Mass. 490; People v. McCann, 16 N. Y. 58, 69 Am. Dec. 642

title: Bureau
body: An ofiice for the transaction of business. A name given to the several departments of the executive or admin istra-tive branch of government, or to their larger subdivisions. In re Strawbridge, 39 Ala. 375

title: Bureaucracy
body: A system in which the business of government is carried on in departments, each under the control of a chief, in contradistinction from a system in which the officers of government have a co-ordinate authority

title: Burg, Burgh
body: A term anciently ap-plied to a castle or fortified place; a borough, (q. v.) Spelman

title: Burgage
body: A name anciently given to a dwelling-house in a borough town. Blount

title: Burgage-Holding
body: A tenure by which lands in royal boroughs in Scotland were held of the sovereign. The service was watching and warding, and was done by the burgesses within the territory of the bor-ough, whether expressed in the charter or not

title: Burgage-Tenure
body: In English law. one of the three species of free socage hold-lngs; a tenure whereby houses and lands which were formerly the site of houses, in an ancient borough, are held of some lord by a certaln rent. There are a great many cus-toms affecting these tenures, the most re

title: Burgator
body: one who breaks into houses or inclosed places, as distinguished from one who committed robbery in the open country. Spelman

title: Burgbote
body: In old Engllsh law. A term applied to a contribution towards the repair of castles or walls of defense, or of a borough

title: Bubgenses
body: In old English law. In-habitants of a burg us or borough; burgesses. Fleta, lib. 5, c. 6, $ 10

title: Burgeristh
body: A word used in Domes-day, signifying a breach o/ the peace in a town. Jacob

title: Burgess
body: In English law. An inhabitant or freeman of a borough or town; a person duly and legally admitted a member of a municipal corporation. Spelman; 3 Steph. Comm. 188, 189

title: Burgess Roll
body: A roll, required by the St. & 6 wm. IV. c. 76, to be kept In corporate towns or boroughs, of the names of burgesses entitled to certain new rights •conferred by that act

title: Burgh-Breche
body: A fine imposed on the community of a town, for a breach of the peace, etc

title: Burgh English
body: See Borough Enq-LISIL

title: Burgh Engloys
body: Borough English, (q. v

title: Burghmails
body: Yearly payments to the crown of Scotland, Introduced by Malcolm III., and resembling the English fee-farm rents

title: Burghmote
body: In Saxon law. A court of Justice held semi-annually by the bishop or lord in a burg, which the thanes were bound to attend without summons

title: Burglariously
body: In pleading. A technical word which must be introduced into an Indictment for burglary at common law. Lewis v. State, 16 Conn. 34; Reed v. State, 14 Tex. App. 665

title: Burglariter
body: L. Lat. (Burglarious-Iy.) In old criminal pleading. A necessary word in Indictments for burglary

title: Burglary
body: In criminal law. The breaking and entering the house of another in the night-time, with intent to commit a felony therein, whether the felony be actual-ly committed or not. Anderson v. State, 48 Ala. 666, 17 Am. Rep. 36; Benson v. McMahon, 127 U. S. 457, 8 Sup. Ct 1240, 32 L. Ed. 234; IIunter v. State, 29 Ind. 80; State v. Petit, 32 wash. 129, 72 Pac. 1021; State v. Langford, 12 N. C. 253; State v. McCall, 4 Ala. 644, 39 Am. Dec. 314; State v. wilson, 1 N. J. Law, 439, 1 Am. Dec. 216; Com. v. Newell, 7 Mass. 245

title: Burgomaster
body: The title given In Germany to the chief executive officer of a borough, town, or city; corresponding to our “mayor

title: Burgundian Law
body: See Lex Bub-ouhdionum

title: Burgwhar
body: A burgess, (q. v

title: Burial
body: Sepulture; the act of interring dead human bodies. See Lay v. State, 12 Ind. App. 362, 39 N. E. 768; In re Reformed, etc., Church, 7 How. Prac. (N. Y.) 476; Cemetery Ass’n v. Assessors, 37 La. Ann. 35

title: Burking-Burkism
body: Murder committed with the object of selling the cadaver for purposes of dissection, particularly and originally, by suffocating or strangling the victim

title: Burlaws
body: In Scotch law. Laws made by neighbors elected by common consent in the burlaw courts. Skene

title: Burn
body: To consume with fire. The verb “to burn,” in an indictment for arson, is to be taken in its common meaning of “to con-sume with fire.” Hester v. State, 17 Ga. 130

title: Burning Fluid
body: As used in policies of insurance, this term does not mean any fluid which will burn, but it means a recog-nized article of commerce, called by that name, and which is a different article from naphtha or kerosene. Putnam v. Insurance Co. (C. C.) 4 Fed. 764; wheeler v. Insurance C0., 6 Mo. App. 235; Mark v. Insurance Co., 24 Hun (N. Y.) 569

title: Burning In The Hand
body: In old Eng-lish criminal law, laymen, upon being ac-corded the benefit of clergy, were burned with a hot iron in the brawn of the left thumb, in order that, being thus marked, they could not again claim thelr clergy. 4 Bl. Comm. 367

title: Burrochium
body: A burroch, dam, or small wear over a river, where traps are laid for the taking of fish. Cowell

title: Burrowmealis
body: In Scotch law. A term used to designate the rents paid into the king’s private treasury by the burgesses or inhabitants of a borough

title: Bursa
body: Lat A purse

title: Bursar
body: A treasurer of a college

title: Burs Aria
body: The exchequer of collegiate or conventual bodies; or the place of receiv-lng, paying, and accounting by the bursars. Also stipendiary scholars, who live upon the burse, fund, or joint-stock of the college

title: Burying Alive
body: In English law. The ancient punishment of sodomites, and those who contracted with Jews. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 27, $ 3

title: Burying-Ground
body: A place set apart for the Interment of the dead; a cemetery. Appeal Tax Court v. Academy, 50 Md. 353

title: Buscarl
body: In Saxon and old English law. Seamen or marines. Spelman

title: Bushel
body: A dry measure, containing four pecks, eight gallons, or thirty-two quarts. But the dimensions of a bushel, and the weight of a bushel of grain, etc., vary in the different states in consequence of statutory enactments. Richardson v. Spafford, 13 Vt

title: Business
body: This word embraces everything about which a person can be employed. People v. Com’rs of Taxes, 23 N. Y. 242, 244

title: Business Hours
body: Those hours of the day during which, in a given community, commercial, banking, professional, public, or oth-er kinds of business are ordinarily car-ried on

title: Busones Gomitatus
body: In old English law. The barons of a county

title: Butlerage
body: A privilege formerly al-lowed to the king’s butler, to take a certain part of every cask of wine imported by an alien

title: Butler'S Ordinance
body: In English law. A law for the heir to punish waste in the life of the ancestor. “Though it be on record in the parliament book of Edward I., yet it never was a statute, nor ever so received; but only some constitution of. the king's council, or lords in parliament, which never obtained the strength or force of an act of parliament.” Hale, Hist. Eng. Law, p. 18

title: Butt
body: A measure of liquid capacity, equal to oue hundred aud eight gallons; also a measure of land

title: Buttals
body: The hounding llnes of land at the end; abuttals, which see

title: Butted And Bounded
body: A phrase sometimes used in conveyancing, to introduce the boundaries of lauds. See Burrs and Bounds

title: Butts And Bounds
body: A phrase used in conveyancing, to describe the end lines or circumscribing lines of a certain piece of land. The phrase “metes and bounds” has the same meaning

title: Butty
body: A local term in the north of England, for the associate or deputy of another ; also of things used in common

title: By-Bidding
body: See Bid

title: By Bill, By Bill Without Writ
body: In practice. Terms anciently used to des-ignate actions commenced by original bill, as distinguished from those commenced by original writ, and applied in modern practice to suits commenced by capias ad respondendum. 1 Arch. Pr. pp. 2, 337; Harkness v. Harkness, 5 Hill (N. Y.) 213.

title: By Estimation
body: In conveyancing. A term used to indicate that the quantity of land as stated is estimated only, not exactly measured; has the same meaning and effect as the phrase "more or less.” Tarbell v. Bowman, 103 Mass. 341; Mendenhall v. Steckel, 47 Md. 453, 28 Am. Rep. 481; Hays v. Hays, 126 Ind. 92, 25 N. E. GOO, 11 L. R. A. 376

title: By God And My Country
body: In old

title: By-Laws
body: Regulations, ordinances, or rules enacted by a private corporation for its own government

title: By Law Men
body: In English law. The chief men of a town, representing the in-habitants

title: By-Road
body: The statute law of New Jer-sey recoguizes three different kinds of roads: A public road, a private road, aud a byroad. A by-road is a road used by the in-habitants, and recognized by statute, but not laid out. Such roads are often called “drift-ways.” They are roads of necessity in new-ly-settled countries. Van Blarcom v. Frike, 29 N. J. Law, 516. See, also, Stevens v. Allen, 29 N. J. Law, 68

title: By The By
body: Incidentally; without new process. A term used in former Engllsh practice to denote the method of filing a dec-laration against a defendant who was al-ready in the custody of the court at the suit of a different plaintiff or of the same plaintiff in another cause

title: Bye-Bil-Wuffa
body: In Hindu law. A deed of mortgage or conditional sale

title: C. A
body: V. An abbreviation for curia ad-visari vult, the court will be advised, will consider, will deliberate

title: C. C
body: P. An abbreviation for Code of Civil Procedure; also for court of common pleas.* ■ •

title: C. L
body: P. Common law procedure, in reference to the English acts so entitled

title: C. O
body: D. "Collect ou delivery.” These letters are not cabalistic, but have a determinate meaning. They import the carrier’s liability to return to the consignor either the goods or the charges. U. S. Exp. Co. v. Keef-er. 59 Iud. 267; Fleming v. Com., 130 Pa. 138. 18 Atl. 622; Express Co. v. wolf, 79 111. 434

title: Cabal
body: A small association for the pur-pose of Intrigue; an intrigue. This name was given to that ministry in the reign of Charles II. formed by Clifford, Ashley, Buck-ingham, Arlington, and Lauderdale, who con-certed a scheme for the restoration of pop-ery. Tlie initials of these five names form the word “cabal;” hence the appellation. Hume, Hist. Eng. is. 69

title: Cabalist
body: In French commercial law. A factor or broker

title: Caballaria
body: Pertaining to a horse. It was a feudal tenure of lands, the tenant furnishing a horseman suitably equipped in time of- war, or when the lord had occasion for his service

title: Caballeria
body: In Spanish law. An allotment of land acquired hy conquest, to a horse soldier. It was a strip one hundred feet wide by two hundred feet deep. The term has been sometimes used in those parts of tlie United States which were derived from Spain. See 12 Pet. 444, note

title: Caballero
body: In Spanish law. A knight. So called on account of its being more honorable to go on horseback (d caballo) than on any other beast

title: Cabinet
body: The advisory board or coun-cil of a king or other chief executive. In the government of the United States the cabinet is composed of the secretary of state, the sec-cretary of the treasury, the secretary of the Interior, the secretary of war, the secretary of the navy, the secretary of agriculture, the secretary of commerce and labor, the attor-ney general, and the postmaster general

title: Cabinet Council
body: In English law. A private and confidential assembly of the most considerable ministers of state, to con-cert measures for the administration of public affairs; first established by Charles I. wharton

title: Cablish
body: Brush-wood, or more prop-erly windfall-wood

title: Cacherellas
body: or CACHERELLAS

title: Cachet, Lettres De
body: Letters is-sued aud signed by the kings of France, and countersigned by a secretary of state, author-izing the imprisonment of a person. Abol-lished during the revolution of 1789

title: Cagicazgos
body: Iu Spanish-American law. Property entailed on the caciques, or heads of Indian villages, • and their descendants. Schm. Civil Lnw, 309

title: Cadastre
body: In Spanish lnw. An official statement of the quantity and value of real property in any district, made for the pur-pose of justly apportioning the taxes payable on such property. 12 Pet 428, note

title: Cadastu
body: In French law. An offldal statement of the quantity and value of realty made for purposes of taxatlon; same as cadastre, (q. r

title: Cadaver
body: A dead human body; a corpse. Cadaver nullius in bonis, no one can have a right of property in a corpse. 3 Co. Inst. 110, 2 Bl. Comm. 429; Griffith v. Rail-road Co., 23 S. C. 32, 55 Am. Rep. 1

title: Cadere
body: Lat To end; cease; fail. As in the phrases eadit actio, (or breve,) the actlon (or writ) fails; eadit assisa, the assise abates; eadit queestio, the discussion ends, there is no room for further argument

title: Cadet
body: In the United States laws

title: Cadi
body: The name of a Turkish clvil mag-lstrate

title: Cadit
body: Lat. It falls, abates, fails, ends, ceases. See Cadbbe

title: Edua
body: UA. In the clvil and old common law. Kept for cuttiug; lntended or used to be cut. A term applled to wood

title: Esar
body: AR. In the Roman law. A cognomen in the Gens Julia, whlch was nssumed by the successors of Julius. Tayl. Civil Law, 31

title: Cjeterus
body: Lat. other; another; the rest

title: Cahier
body: In old French law. -A list of grievances prepared for deputies in the states-general. A petition for the redress of griev-ances enumerated

title: Cairns' Act
body: An English statute for enabling the court of chancery to award dam-ages. 21 & 22 Vict. c. 27

title: Calaboose
body: A term used vulgarly, and occasionally in judicial proceedings nud law reports, to designate a jail or prison, partic-uarly a town or city jail or lock-up. Suppos-ed to be a corruption of the Spanish calabozo, a dungeon. See Gilliam v. wells, 64 Ga. 194

title: Calcetum, Calcea
body: A causeway, or common hard-way, maintained and repnir-ed with stones and rubbish

title: Calefagium
body: lu old law. A right to tuke fuel yearly. Cowell

title: Calendar
body: 1. The established order of the division of time into years, months, weeks, and days; or a systematized enumera-tion of such arrangement; an almanac. Rives v. Guthrie, 46 N. C. 86

title: Calends
body: Among the Romans the first day of every month, being spoken of by it-self, or the very day of the new moon, which usually happen together. And if pridie, the day before, be added to it, then it is the last day of the foregoing month, as pridie calend. Beptemb. is the last day of August. If any number be placed wlth it, it signifies that day in the former month which comes so much before the month named, as the tenth calends of october is the 20th day of September; for if one reckons backwards, beginning at october, that 20th day of September makes the 10th day before october. In March, May, July, and october, the .calends begin at the sixteenth day, but in other months at the fourteenth; which calends must ever bear the name of the month following, and be numbered backwards from the first day of the said following months. Jacob. See Rives v. Guthrie, 46 N. C. 87

title: Calends, Greek
body: A metaphorical expression for a tlme never likely to arrive

title: Calpes
body: ln Scotch law. A gift to the bead of a clan, as an acknowledgment for protection and maintenance

title: Calumnia
body: In tbe civil law. Cal-nmny, malice, or ill design; a false accusa-tion; a malicious prosecution. Lanning ▼. Christy, 30 ohio St. 115, 27 Am. Rep. 43L

title: Calumnis Juramentum
body: In the

title: Calumnis Jusjurandum
body: The

title: Calumniator
body: In the civil law. One who accused another of a crime wlthout cause; one who brought a false accusation. Cod. 9, 46

title: Calumny
body: Defamation; slander; false accusation of a crime or offense. See Cal-UMNIA

title: Camara
body: In Spanish law. A treasury. Las Partidas, pt 6, tit. 3, 1, 2

title: Cambipartigeps
body: A champertor

title: Cambist
body: In mercantile law. A per-eon skilled in exchanges; one who trades in promlssory notes and bills of exchange

title: Cambium
body: In the civil law. Change or exchange. A term applied indifferently to the exchange of land, money, or debts

title: Cameba
body: In old English law. A chamber, room, or apartment; a judge’s cham-ber; a treasury; a chest or coffer. Also, a stipend payable from vassal to lord; an an-nuity

title: Cameralistics
body: The science of fl-nance or public revenue, comprehending the means of raising and disposing of it

title: Camino
body: In Spanish law. A road or highway. Las Partidas, pt. 3, tlt 2, 1. 6

title: Campana
body: In old European law. A bell. Spelman

title: Campanarium, Campanile
body: A

title: Campartum
body: A part of a larger field or ground, which would otherwise be in gross or in common

title: Campebs
body: A share; a champertor’s share; a champertous division or sharing of land

title: Campertum
body: A corn-field; a field of grain. Blount; Cowell; Jacob

title: Campfight
body: In old English law. The fighting of two champions or combatants in the field; the judlclal combat, or duellum. 3 lnst. 22L

title: Campus
body: In old European law. An

title: Cana
body: A Spanish measure of length varying (in different localities) from about five to seven feet

title: Canal
body: An artificial ditch or trench in the earth, for confining water to a defined channel, to be used for purposes of transportation

title: Cancel
body: To obliterate, strike, or cross out; to destroy the effect of an instrument by defacing, obliterating, expunging, or erasing it

title: Cangellaria
body: Chancery; the conrt of chancery. Curia canccllaria is also used in the same seuse. See 4 Bl. Comm. 46; Cowell

title: Cancellarius
body: A chancellor; a scrivener, or notary. A janltor, or one who stood at the door of the court and was ac-customed to carry out the commands of the judges

title: Candidate
body: A person who offers himself, or is presented by others, to be elected to an office. Derived from the Latin Candidas, (white,) because in Rome it was the custom for those who sought office to clothe themselves in whlte garments

title: Candlemas-Day
body: In English law

title: Canonry
body: In English ecclesiastical law. An ecclesiastical benefice, attachlng to the office of canon. Holthouse

title: Cant
body: In the civll law. A method of dlviding property held in common by two or more joint owners. See Hayes v. Cuuy, 9 Mart. O. S. (La.) 87

title: Canterbury, Archbishop Of
body: In English eccleslastlcal law. The primate of all England; the chief ecclesiastical digni-tary in the church. Hls customary privilege is to crown tlie kings and queens of England; while the Archbishop of York bas the prlvl-lege to crown the queen consort, and be her perpetual chaplain. The Archblshop of Can-terbury has also, by £5 Hen. VIII. c. 21, the power of granting dlspensatlons in any case not coutrary to the holy scriptures and the law of God, where the pope used formerly to graut them, which is the foundation of his granting special licenses to marry at any place or time; to hold two llvings, (which must be confirmed under the great seal.) and the like; and on this also is founded the right he exercises of conferring degrees in prejudice of the two universities, wharton.

title: Cantred
body: A district comprising a hun-dred villages; a hundred. A term used in wales in tlie same sense as “hundred” is in England. Cowell; Termes de la Ley

title: Canum
body: In feudal law. A species of duty or tribute payable from tenant to lord, usually consisting of produce of the land

title: Canvass
body: The act of examining and counting the returns of votes cast at a pub-lic election. Bowler v. Elsenhood, 1 S. Dak. 577, 48 N. W. 136, 12 L. R. A. 705; Clark v. Tracy, 95 lowa, 410, 64 N. W. 290; Hudson v. Solomon, 19 Kan. 180; People v. Sausalito, 106 Cal. 500, 39 Pac. 937; In re Stew-art, 24 App, Dlv. 201, 48 N, Y. Supp. 957

title: Capacity
body: Legal capacity is the attri-bute of a person who can acquire new rights, or transfer rights, or assume duties, accord-ing to the mere dictates of his own will, as manifested in juristic acts, without any restraint or hindrance arising from his status or legal condition

title: Cap Ax Doli
body: Lat Capable of committing crime, or capable of criminal Intent. The phrase describes the condition of one who has sufficient Intelligence and compre-hension to be held criminally responsible for hls deeds

title: Capax Negoth
body: Competent to transact affairs; having business capacity

title: Cape
body: In Engllsh practice. A judicial writ touching a plea of . lands or tenements, divlded lnto cape magnum, or the grand cape, whlch lay before "appearance to sum* mon the tenant to answer the default, and also over to the demandant; the cape ad valentiam was a species of grand cape, and cape parvum, or petit cape, after appearance or vlew granted, summoning the tenant to answer the default only. Termes de la Ley; 3 Steph. Comm. 606, note

title: Capella
body: In old records. A box, cabinet, or repository in which were pre-served the relics of martyrs. Spelman. A small building in which relics were preserv-ed; an oratory or chapel. Id

title: Capers
body: Vessels of war owned by pri-vate persons, and different from ordinary prlvateers only in size, belng smaller. Beawes, Lex Merc. 230

title: Capias
body: I^at. “That you take." The general name for several species of writs, the common characteristic of which is that they require the officer to take the body of the defendant into custody; they are writs of at-tachmeut or arrest

title: Capiatur Pro Fine
body: (Let him be taken for the fine.) In English practice. A clause inserted at the end of old judgment records in actions of debt, where the defend-ant denied bis deed, and it was found against

title: Capita
body: Heads, and, figuratively, en-tire bodies, whether of persons or animals. Spelman

title: Capital Stock
body: The common stock or fund of a corporation. The sum of money raised by the subscriptions of the stockhold-ers, and dlvlded into shares. It is sald to he the sum upon which calls may be made upon the stockholders, and dividends are to he paid. Christensen v. Eno, 106 N. Y. 97, 12 N. E. 648, 60 Am. Rep. 429; People v. Com’rs, 23 N. Y. 219; State v. Jones, 51 ohio St. 492. 37 N. E. 945; Burrall v. Railroad Go., 75 N. Y. 216

title: Capitals
body: A thing which is stolen, or the value of it. Blount

title: Capitals Vtvens
body: Live cattle. Blonnt

title: Capitalis
body: In old English law. Chief, principal; at the head. A term applied to

title: Capitaneus
body: A tenant in capite. He who held his land or title directly from the king himself. A captain; a naval commander

title: Capitatim
body: Lat. By the head; by the poll; severally to each individual

title: Capitation Tax
body: AX. one which is levied upon the person simply, without any reference to his property, real or personal, or to any business in which he may be engaged, or to any employment which he may follow. Gardner v. Hall, 61 N. C. 22; Leedy v. Bourbon, 12 Ind. App. 486, 40 N. E. 640; Head-Money Cases (C. C.) 18 Fed. 139

title: Capite
body: Lat. By the head. Tenure in capite was an ancient feudal tenure, whereby a man held lands of the king immedtate-ly. It was of two sorts,—the one, principal and general, or of the king as the source of all tenure; the other, special and subaltern, or of a particular subject. It is now abolish-ed. Jacob. As to distribution per capita, see Capita

title: Capite Minutus
body: In tlie civil law. one who had suffered capitis diminutio, one who lost status or legal attributes. See Dig. 4, 5

title: Capitis Diminutio
body: In Romnn law. A diminishing or abridgment of personality. This was a loss or curtailment of a man’s status or aggregate of legal attributes and qualifications, following upon certain changes in his civll condition. It was of three kinds, enumerated as follows

title: Capititium
body: A covering for the head, mentioned in St. 1 Hen. IV. nnd other old statutes, which prescribe what dresses shall be worn by all degrees of persons. Jacob

title: Capitula
body: Collections of laws and ordinances drawn up under heads of divisions. Spelman

title: Capitulary
body: In Frenob law. A

title: Capitulation
body: In military law

title: Capituli Agri
body: Head-fields; lands lying at the head or upper end of furrows etc

title: Cappa
body: In old records. A cap. Cappa honoris, the cap of honor, one of the solemnities or ceremonies of creating an earl or marqals

title: Captain
body: A head-man; commander; commanding officer. The captain of a war-vessel is the oflicer first in command. In the Unlted States navy, the rank of “captain” is intermediate between that of “comma nd-er” and “commodore.” The governor or con-trolling officer of a vessel in the merchant service is usually styled “captain" by the in-ferior officers nnd seamen, bnt in maritime business and admiralty law is more commonly designated as “master.” In foreign juris-prudence his title is often that of “patron.” in the United States army (and the militia) the captain is the commander of a company of soldiers, one of the divisions of a regiment. The term is also used to designate the com-mander of a squad of municipal poljce

title: Captation
body: In French law. The act of one who succeeds in controlling the will of another, so as to become master of it; used In an Invidious sense. Zerega v. Percl-val, 46 La. Ann. 590. 15 South. 470

title: Captator
body: A person who obtains a gift or legacy through artifice

title: Captio
body: In old English law and practice. A taking or seizure; arrest; receiving; holding of court

title: Caption
body: In praotioe. That part of a legal instrument, as a commission, indict-ment, etc., whlch shows where, when, nnd by what authority it is taken, found, or executed. State v. Sutton, 5 N. C. 281; U. S. v. Beebe, 2 Dak. 292, 11 N. W. 505; State v. Jones, 9 N. J. Law, 365, 17 Am. Dec. 483

title: Captives
body: Prisoners of war. As in the goods of an enemy, so also in his person, a sort of qualified property may be acquired, by taking him a prisoner of war, at least till his ransom be paid. 2 Bl. Comm. 402

title: Captor
body: In international law. one who takes or seizes property in time of war; one who takes the property of an enemy. In a stricter sense, one who takes a prize at sea. 2 Bl. Comm. 401; 1 Kent, Comm. 86, 96, 103

title: Capture
body: In international law. Tbe taking or wresting of property from one of two belligerents by the other. It occurs either on land or at sea. In the former case, the property captured is called “booty;” in the latter case, “prize.”

title: Caput
body: A head; the head of a person; the whole person; the life of a person; one’s personality; status; civil condition

title: Cafutagium
body: In old English law. Head or poll money, or the payment of it. Cowell; Blonnt

title: Oaputium
body: In old Engllsh law. A head of land; a headland. Cowell

title: Oarabus
body: In old English law. A kind of raft or boat Spelmau

title: Carcanum
body: A gaol; a prison

title: Carcare
body: In old English law. To load; to load a vessel; to freight

title: Cardinal
body: In ecclesiastical law. A dignitary of the court of Rome, next in rank to the pope

title: Cards
body: In criminal law. Small palters or pasteboards of an oblong or rectangular shape, on which are printed figures or points, used in playing certain games. See Estes v. State, 2 Humph. (Tenn.) 496; Common-wealth v. Arnold, 4 Pick. (Mass.) 251; State v. Herryford, 19 Mo. 377; State v. Lewis, 12 W1S. 434

title: Care
body: As a legal term, this word means dlligence, prudence, discretion, attentiveness, watchfulness, vlgilance. It is the opposite of negligence or carelessness

title: Carena
body: A term nsed in the old ecclesiastical law to denote a period of forty days

title: Carence
body: In French law. Lack of a»* sets; insolvency. A procds-verbol de carence is a document setting out that the huissier attended to issue execution upon a judgment, but found nothing upon which to levy. Arg. Fr. Merc. Law, 547

title: Carectarius
body: or CARECTARIUS. A

title: Carga
body: In Spanlsh law. An Incumbrance; a charge, white, New Recop. b. 2, tlt 13, c. 2, | 2

title: Cargaison
body: In French commercial law. Cargo; lading

title: Cargare
body: In old Engllsh law. To charge. Spelman

title: Cargo
body: In mercantlle law. The load or lading of a vessel; goods and merchandise put on board a ship to be carried to a certain port

title: Cariagium
body: In old English law. Carriage; the carrying of goods or other things for the klng

title: Caristia
body: Dearth, scarcity, dearness

title: Cark
body: In old English law. A quantity of wool, whereof thirty make a sarplar. (The latter is equal to 2,240 pounds in weight.) St 27 Hen. VI. c. 2. Jacob

title: Carlisle Tables
body: Life and annuity tables, compiled at Carlisle, England, about 1780. Used by actuaries, etc

title: Carmen
body: In the Roman law. Literally, a verse or song. A formula or form of words used on various occasions, as of divorce. Tayl. Clvll Law, 349

title: Carnal
body: Of the body; relating to the body; fleshly; sexual

title: Carnauter
body: In old criminal law. Carnally. Camaliter cognovit, carnally knew. Technlcal words in Indictments for rape, and held essential. 1 Hale, P. C. 637-639

title: Carnally Knew
body: In pleading. A technical phrase essential in an indictment to charge the defendant with the crime of rape

title: Caroome
body: In Engllsh law. A license by the lord mayor of London to keep a cart

title: Carpemeals
body: Cloth made in the northern parts of England, of a coarse klnd, mentioned in 7 Jac. I. c. 16. Jacob

title: Carrera
body: In Spanish law. A carriageway; the right of a carriage-way. Las Partidas, pt. 3, tit. 31, L 3

title: Carriage
body: A vehicle used for the transportation of persons either for pleasure or business, and drawn by horses hr other draught animals over the ordinary streets and highways of the country; not including cars used exclusively upou railroads or street railroads expressly constructed for the use of such cars. Snyder v. North Lawrence, 8

title: Carry
body: To bear, bear about, sustain, transport, remove, or convey

title: Cart
body: A carriage for luggage or burden, with two wheels, as distinguished from a wagon, which has four wheels. The vehicle in which criminals are taken to execution

title: Cart Bote
body: wood or timber which a tenant is allowed by law to tuke from an es-tate, for the purpose of repairing instruments, (including necessary vehicles,) of husbandry. 2 Bl. Comm. 35

title: Carta
body: In old English law. A charter, or deed. Any written instrument

title: Carta De Foresta
body: In old English law. The charter of the forest More coiu-monly called “Charta de Forcsta," (q. v

title: Carte
body: In French marine law. A chart

title: Carte Blanche
body: A white sheet of paper; an Instrument signed, but otherwise left blank. A sheet given to an agent, with the principal’s signature appended, to be Ailed up with any contract or engagement as the agent mny see fit. Hence, metaphorically, unlimited authority

title: Cartel
body: An agreement between two hostile powers for the delivery of prisoners

title: Cartmen
body: Carriers who transport goods aud merchandise in carts, usually for short distances, for hire

title: Cartulary
body: A place where papers or records are kept

title: Carua
body: A, or CARUA. A plow

title: Carucage
body: In old English law. A kind of tax or tribute anciently lmposed upon every plow, (carve or plow-land,) for the public service. Spelman

title: Carucata
body: A certain quantity of land used as the basis for taxation. As much land as may be tilled by a single plow in a year and a day. Also, a team of cattle, or a cart-load

title: Carucatarius
body: one who held lands in cartage, or plow-tenure. Cowell

title: Carue
body: A carve of land; plow-land. Britt, c. 84

title: Carvage
body: The name as caracage, (q. ©.) Cowell

title: Carve
body: In old English law. A caru-cate or plow-land

title: Cas Fortuit
body: Fr. In the law of ln-surance. A fortuitous event; an Inevitable accident

title: Casata
body: In old English law. A house with land sufficient for the support of one family, otherwise called “bide,” a hide of land, and by Bede, "familia.” Spelman

title: Casatus
body: A vassal or feudal tenant possessing a cosata; that is, having a house, household, and property of his own

title: Case
body: 1. A general term for an action, danse, suit, or controversy, at law or in equity; a question contested before a court of Justice; an aggregate of facts which fur-nlshes occasion for the exercise of the juris-dlction of a court of Justice. Smith v. wa-terbury. 54 Conn. 174, 7 Atl. 17; Kundolf v. Thalheimer, 12 N. Y. 596; Gebhard v. Sat-tler, 40 Iowa, 156

title: Case Law
body: A professional name for the aggregate of reported cases as forming a body of jurisprudence; or for the law of a particular subject as evidenced or formed by the adjudged cases; in distinction to statutes and other sources of law

title: Cash
body: Ready money; whatever can be used as money without heing converted into another form; that which circulates as money, including bank-bills. Hooper v. Flood, 54 Cal. 221; Dazet v. Landry, 21 Nev. 291, 30 Pac. 1064; Blair v. wilson, 28 Grat. (Va.) 165; Haviland v. Chace, 39 Barb. (N. Y.) 284

title: Cashlite
body: An amercement or fine; a mulct

title: Cass Are
body: To quash; to render vold; to break

title: Cassation
body: In French law. Annul-ling; reversal; breaking the force nnd va-lldlty of a judgment. A decision emanating

title: Cassation, Court Of
body: (Fr. eour de cassation.) The highest court in France; so termed from possessing the power to quash (casser) the decrees of inferior courts. It is a court of appeal in crimlnal as well as civil cases

title: Cassetur Billa
body: (Lat That the bill be quashed.) In practlce. The form of the judgment for the defendant on a plea in abatement, where the action was commenced by bill, (billa.) 3 Bl. Comm. 303; Steph. Pl. 128, 131. The form of an entry made hy a plaintiff on the record, after a plea in abatement, where he found that the plea could not be confessed and avoided, nor traversed, nor demurred to; amounting in fact to a discontinuance of the action. 2 Archb. Pr. K. B. 8, 236; 1 Tidd, Pr. 683

title: Cassetur Breve
body: (Lat That the writ be quashed.) In practice. The form of the judgment for the defendant on a plea in abatement, where the action was commenced hy original writ, (breve.) 3 Bl. Comm. 303; Steph. Pl. 107, 109

title: Oastellain
body: In old Engllsh law. The lord, owner, or captain of a castle; the constable of a fortified house; a person having the custody of one of the crown mansions; an officer of the forest

title: Oastellanus
body: A castellaln; the keeper or constable of a castle. Spelman

title: Castellarium, Oastellatus
body: In old Engllsh law. The preclnct or juris-diction of a castle. Blonnt

title: Castellorum Oferatio
body: In Sax-on and old English law. Castle work. Serv-ice and labor done by Inferior tenants for the bulldlng and upholding castles and pub-lic places of defense, one of the three *nec-essary charges, (trinoda ncccssitas.) to which all lands among the Saxons were expressly subject Cowell

title: Castigatory
body: An engine used to punish women who have been convicted of being common scolds. It is sometimes called the “trebucket," “tumbrel,” “ducking-stool," or “cucking-stool.” U. S. v. Royall, 27 Fed. Cas. 907

title: Casting Vote
body: where the votes of a deliberative assembly or legislative body are equally divided on any question or motion, it is the privilege of the presiding offl-cer to cast one vote (lf otherwise he would not he entitled to any vote) on either side, or to cast one additional vote, if he has al-ready voted as a member of the body. This is called the “casting vote.”

title: Castleguard
body: In feudal law. An imposition anciently laid upon such persons as lived within a certain distance of any castle, towards the maintenance, bf such as watched and warded the castle

title: Castrensis
body: In the Roman law. Relating to the camp or military service

title: Casu Consimili
body: In old Engllsh law. A writ of entry, granted where tenant hy the curtesy, or tenant for life, allenated in fee, or in tail, or for another’s llfe, whlch was brought by him in reversion against the party to whom such tenant so alienated to

title: Casu Proviso
body: A writ of entry framed under the provisions of the statute of Gloucester, (6 Edw. I.,) c. 7, which lay for the benefit of the reversioner when a ten-ant in dower aliened in fee or for life

title: Casual
body: That which happens accident-ally, or is brought about by causes un* known; fortuitous; the result of chance. Lewis v. Lofley, 92 Ga. 804, 19 S. E. 57

title: Casualty
body: Inevitable accldent; an event not to be foreseen or guarded against A loss from such an event or cause; as by fire, shipwreck, lightning, etc. Story, Bailm. $ 240; Gill v. Fugate, 117 Ky. 257, 78 S. W. 191; McCarty v. Railroad Co., 30 Pa. 251; Railroad Co. v. Car Co., 139 U. S. 79, 11 Sup. Ct. 490, 35 L. Ed. 97; Ennls v. Bldg. Ass'n, 102 Iowa, 520, 71 N. W. 426; Anthony v. Karbach, 64 Neb. 509, 90 N. W. 243, 97 Am. St. Rep. 662

title: Catalla
body: In old English Law. Chattels. The word among the Normans prlma-rlly signified only beasts of husbandry, or, as they are still called, “cattle,” but, in a secondary sense, the term was applied to all movables in general, and not only to these, but to whatever was not a fief or fend, wharton

title: Catallis Oaptis Nomine Dis-Trictionis
body: An obsolete writ that lay where a house was within a borough, for rent issuing out of the same, and which war-ranted the taking of doors, windows, etc., by way of distress

title: Catallis Reddendis
body: For the re

title: Catallum
body: A chattel. Most frequent-ly used in the plural form, catalla, (q. v

title: Catals
body: Goods and chattels. See Ca-talla

title: Oataneus
body: A tenant in capite. A tenant holding immediately of the crown. Spelman

title: Oatascopus
body: An old name for an archdeacon

title: Catching Bargain
body: See Bargain

title: Catchings
body: Things caught, and in the possession, custody, power, and dominion of the party, with a present capacity to use them for hls own purposes. The term includes blubher, dr pieces of whale flesh cut from the whale, and stowed on or under the deck of a. ship. A policy of lnsurance upon out-fits, and cntchings substituted for the outfits, in a whaling voyage, protects the blubber. Rogers v. Insurance Co., 1 Story, 603; Fed. Cas. No. 12.016; 4 Law Rep. 297

title: Catchland
body: Land In Norfolk, so call-ed because it is not known to what parish it belongs, and the minister who first seizes the tithes of it, by right of preoccupation, enjoys them for that year. Cowell

title: Catchpoll
body: LL. A name formerly given to a sheriff's deputy, or to a constable, or other officer whose duty it is to arrest persons. He was a sort of serjeant The word is not now in use as an official designation. Minshew

title: Cater Cousin
body: (From Fr. Quatrecousin.) A cousin in the fourth degree; hence any distant or remote relative

title: Cathedral
body: In English ecclesiastical law. The church of the blshop of the dlo-cese, in which is his cathedra, or throne, nnd his special Jurisdiction; in that respect the principal church of the diocese

title: Catholic Emancipation Aot
body: The statute of 10 Geo. IV. c. 7, by which Ro-man Catholics were restored, in general, to the full enjoyment of all civil rights, except tiiat of holding ecclesiastical offices, and certain high appointments in the state. 3 Steph. Comm. 109.

title: Catoniana Regula
body: In Roman law. The rule which is commonly expressed in the maxim, Quod ab initio non valet tractu temporis non convalebit, meaning that what is at the beginning void by reason of some technical (or other) legal defect will not become valid merely by length of time. The rule applied to the institution of /itrredes, the bequest of legacies, and such like. The rule is not without Its application also in En-glish law; e. g., a marrled woman’s will (be-ing void when made) is not made valid mere-ly because she lives to become a widow. Brown

title: Cattle
body: A term which includes the domestic animals generally; all the animals used by man for labor or food

title: Cauda Terrs
body: A land’s end, or the bottom of a ridge in arable land. Cowell

title: Caulceis
body: Highroads or ways pitched with flint or other stones

title: Caupona
body: In the civil law. An lnn er tavern. Inst 4, 5, 3

title: Caupones
body: In the civil law. Innkeep-ers. Dig. 4, 9 ; Id. 47, 5; Story, Ag. $ 458

title: Caursines
body: Italian merchants who came into England in the reign of Henry III., where they established themselves as money lenders, hut were soon expelled for their usury and extortion. Cowell; Blount

title: Caucus
body: A meeting of the legal voters of any political party assembled for the purpose of choosing delegates or for the noraina-tion of candidates for office. Pub. St. N. H

title: Causa
body: Lat. 1. A cause, reason, occasion, motive, or Inducement

title: Causam Nobis Significes Quare
body: A writ addressed to a mayor of a town, etc., who was by the king's writ com-manded to give seisin of lands to the king's grantee, on hls delaying to do it, requiring him to show cause why he so delayed the per-formance of his duty. Blount; Cowell

title: Causare
body: In the civil and old English law. To be engaged in a suit; to litl-gate; to conduct a cause

title: Causator
body: In old European law. one who manages or litigates another’s cause Spelman

title: Cause
body: That which*produces an effect; whatever moves, impels, or leads. The ori-gin or foundation of a thing, as of a suit or action; a ground of'action. Corning v. McCullough, 1 N. Y. 47, 49 Am. Dec. 287; State v. Dougherty, 4 or. 203

title: Cause-Books
body: Books kept in the central office of the English supreme court, in whlch are entered all wrlts of summons issued in the office. Rules of Court, v 8

title: Cause List
body: In English practice. A printed roll of actions, to be tried in the order of thelr entry, with the names of the solicitors for each litigant Similar to the calendar of causes, or docket, used in Amer-lcan courts

title: Cause Of Action
body: Matter for which an action may be brought. The ground on which an action may be sustained. The right to bring a suit

title: Causidicus
body: In the civil law. Aplead-er; one who argued a cause ore tenus

title: Cautela
body: Lat Care; caution; vigi-lance; prevision

title: C Autio
body: In tbe oivil and Frenob law

title: Caution
body: In Scotch law, and in admi-ralty law. Surety; security; bail; an un-dertaklng by way of surety. 6. Mod. 162. See Cautio

title: Cautionary
body: In Scotch law. An instrument in whlch a person hinds himself as surety for another

title: Cautione Admittenda
body: In Eng-lish ecclesiastical law. A writ that lies against a bishop who holds an excommunl-cated person in prison for contempt, not-withstandlng he offers sufficient caution or security to obey the orders and commandment of the church for the future. Reg. Orig. 66; CowelL

title: Cautioner
body: In Scotch law. A surety; a bondsman, one who binds himself in a bond wlth the principal for greater security. He is still a cautioner whether the bond be to pay a debt, or whether he undertake to produce the person of the party for whom he is bound. Bell

title: Cauctonnement
body: In French law. The same as becoming surety in English law

title: Cautionry
body: In Scotch law. Surety-ship

title: Caveat
body: Lat Let him beware. A formal notice or warning given by a party ln-terested to a court, judge, or ministerial offl-cer against tbe performance of certain acts within his power and jurisdiction. This process may be used in the proper courts to pre-vent (temporarily or provisionally) the prov-lng of a will or the grant of admlnistration, or to arrest the enrollment of a decree in chancery when the party Intends to take an appeal, to prevent the grant of letters patent, etc. It is also used, in the American prac-tlce, as a kind of equitable process, to stay the granting of a patent for lauds, wilson v. Gaston, 92 Pa. 207; Slocum v. Grandin, 38 N. J. Eq. 485; Ex parte Crafts, 28 S. C. 281, 6 S. E. 718; In re Miller's Estate, 166 Pa. 97, 81 Atl. 58

title: Caveat Aotor
body: Let the doer, or actor, beware

title: Caveat Emptor
body: OR. Let the buyer take care. This maxim summarizes the rule that the purchaser of an article must examine, judge, and test it for himself, being bound to discover any obvious defects or imperfec-tions. Miller v. Tiffany, 1 wall. 309, 17 L. Ed. 540; Barnard v. Kellogg, 10 wall. 388, 19 L. Ed. 987; Slaughter v. Gerson, 13 wall. 383, 20 L. Ed. 627; Hargous v. Stone, 5 N. Y. 82; wissler v. Craig, 80 Va. 32; wright v. Hart, 18 wend. (N. Y.) 453

title: Caveat Venditor
body: In Roman law

title: Caveat Viator
body: Let the traveler beware. This phrase has been used as a concise expression of the dnty of a traveler on the highway to use due care to detect and avoid

title: Cavere
body: Lat in the civil and common law. To take care; to exercise caution; to take care or provide for; to provide by law; to provide against; to forbid by law; ’to give security; to give caution or security on arrest

title: Cavers
body: Persons stealing ore from mines in Derbyshire, punishable in the bergh-mote or miners’ court; also officers beloug-ing to the same mines, wharton

title: Caya
body: In old English law. A quay, kay, key, or wharf. Cowell

title: Cayagium
body: In old English law. Cay-age or kayage; a toll or duty anciently pald for landing goods at a quay or wharf. Cow-ell

title: Ceap
body: A bargain; anything for sale; a chattel; also cattle, as being the usual medl-um of barter. Sometimes used instead of ceapgild, (q. v

title: Ceapgild
body: Payment or forfeiture of an animal. An ancient species of forfeiture
